“I once choked on an exploding balloon.”
~ Oscar Wilde on balloons

~ NENA on 99 red balloons

A great way to evade the cops.

Balloons are mobile, economic traps for Evil Spirits. They are usually made from rubber, but sometimes from more exotic substances such as cloth, animal bladders, mylar, foil and mango. In modern society, people carelessly and foolishly inflate balloons and blow them up for fun, thus releasing a horde of horrible, destructive forces upon themselves and others.


Balloons are creatures from the ballonicus blownupicus domain of higheria. They are born as little flat things yearning for an "inflatorcus" to blow them up. Some balloons do not like the air they get and just blow it back out because they want hot air, helium or hydrogen. Some balloons called pencil balloons take up a really long shape and refuse any air altogether until they find an actor or clown who knows how to blow these balloons up. A lucky few balloons find helium hot air or hydrogen. People usually set these balloons free when they are done with them for humane reasons; unless of course they are evil environmentalists who pop them. When a balloon is popped it is reincarnated as a new balloon so it can try again to reach the home star. Sometimes a helium or hydrogen balloon will take other air filled balloons with it on its journey to home. Donkeys like balloons; but they are too large for piglets to get on with.


People have found use for the balloon and domesticated it. Some domesticated balloons are blown up very big and sometimes carry people to the moon and beyond, or on other short needless flights, such as balloon boy's very famous flight across Colorado. Pencil balloons are often domesticated by actors, actresses and clowns as they are the only people who can blow them up. They are then twisted and given to children who neglect them and let them die, or pop them. Some balloons are inflated by children for fun, and then just left to die. A few helium balloons are used for Balloon Huffing where the helium, air, or hydrogen is sucked out of them.


Balloons are slaves to humans from the time of their inflation to the time that the float away. Balloons usually serve the one who inflated them, but they will sometimes allow transfers of their services to another bunny wabbit. The will go wherever their master wants them to, even into his lungs when used for balloon huffing. When huffed, the soul of the balloon enters the person's lungs, and the person is granted a magic wish if it is said in helium voice. People who are humane to balloons will usually let them free when they are done with them so they can join the many other freed balloons.

Mass marketing

Soon after the beginning of balloon mass-manufacturing came the important art of balloon tying. By twisting the trapped evil spirit along certain energy points (Chakras) of its astral body, the spirit's telepathic powers diminish and people are less prone to blow the tied balloon up.

The effectiveness of this device proved fatal to the evil spirit community, and in a special conference they have decided to fight back with a clever scheme. After an extensive research of the human psyche, evil spirits learned that we humans can't resist the primordial urge to make funny noises. Therefore they hid themselves in special balloons called "Helium" (Hell-ium!) and waited for people to inhale them. Then, for a short while, the evil spirits would distort the voices of the inhalers in a funny way. This plan worked better than expected, and all over the world people just can't wait to get their hands on some balloons and release more and more evil spirits into the world.

Balloon Demons, as they are formally known, can also be captured while blowing soap bubbles at them. This method works only in emergencies because Balloon Demons can force soap bubbles to pop themselves randomly. After the Demon has freed himself from a soap bubble, it is usually very tired from the procedure. If many soap bubbles are present, you can continue to recapture it until it dies of exhaustion! Otherwise, quickly get a balloon talisman and capture the demon permanently.

"Billy's" Balloon

While most people align balloons as child's play and comforting floating plastic objects. There is the danger of a balloon entering a stage called "billy's" balloon, which is caused by over use of a balloon. Seeing how balloons are made to entrap the souls of serial killers and people who just really hate children, my best advice is to just run like hell if your balloon goes into this stage of insanity and find the nearest pointy object in your house. If your outside then your just fucked, but hey better you than me. Most people believe that this disease is a myth but those people are usually the ones who didn't watch Don Hertzfeldt's cartoon of prophecy.

But watch out, if this is not contained properly, then the balloons will succeed in their co-operative attack on humanity with the Zombies. And if the Zombie-Balloon apocalypse comes then there is no where to hide. Water, Skyscrapers, bunkers it doesn't matter, THEY WILL FIND YOU!

# **Scene Concept: "The Balloon Emporium Workshop"**  

## **Overall Scene Theme and Core Concept**  
A whimsical yet slightly unnerving workshop where balloons are not just party decorations but vessels for mysterious energies. The **Balloon Emporium** is a bustling, cluttered space where artisans, scientists, and eccentric collectors collaborate to inflate, modify, and sometimes *contain* the strange phenomena balloons exhibit.  

The environment is **inherently collaborative** due to:  
- **Heavy, unwieldy equipment** (helium tanks, industrial inflators) requiring multiple operators.  
- **Precision tasks** (tying complex knots, adjusting gas mixtures) needing coordination.  
- **Strange anomalies** (floating objects, rogue balloons) that require real-time problem-solving.  

Atmosphere: A mix of carnival whimsy and clandestine laboratory—bright colors, but with ominous undertones (whispering balloons, flickering lights).  

---  

## **Spatial Layout and Area Descriptions**  
The **Emporium** is divided into four key zones:  

1. **Main Workshop Floor** – Central hub with worktables, gas tanks, and active inflation stations.  
2. **The Archive** – A cramped side-room with labeled drawers containing "specialized" balloons (some sealed in glass cases).  
3. **Testing Chamber** – A reinforced plexiglass cube where volatile balloons are observed.  
4. **Storage & Prep** – Cluttered backroom with crates of supplies and deflated "raw" balloons.  

---  

## **Detailed Area-by-Area Inventory**  

### **1. Main Workshop Floor**  
**a. Anchor Furniture & Installations:**  
- **Industrial Helium Tank Array** – Three tanks (1m tall, 40cm diameter) bolted to the floor, connected via rubber hoses. Pressure gauges show varying levels (one is near-empty).  
- **Central Worktable** – Steel-framed, 3m x 2m, scuffed surface stained with rainbow latex smears.  
- **Overhead Hoist System** – For lifting large balloon clusters (max load: 150kg).  

**b. Key Interactive & Task-Relevant Objects:**  
- **Pneumatic Inflator No. 7** – Currently jammed (display shows "ERROR: PRESSURE OVERFLOW"). Requires two people to reset (one holds release valve, other reboots control panel).  
- **"Chroma-Knot" Balloon Tier** – A mechanical device for auto-tying balloons, but the red adjustment dial is loose, causing inconsistent seals.  
- **The "Billy" Balloon (Quarantined)** – Suspended in a wire cage, faintly pulsing. Label: *"DO NOT INHALE. DO NOT MAKE EYE CONTACT."*  

**c. Functional Ambient Objects:**  
- **Scattered Hand Pumps** – Some clogged with glitter residue.  
- **Gas Mixing Station** – Helium/Nitrogen/Oxygen valves, one dripping.  
- **Wall-Mounted Intercom** – Crackling faint static, occasionally a distant hum.  

**d. Background & Decorative Objects:**  
- **Framed "Balloon Animal Championships" Poster (2008)** – Fading, one corner torn.  
- **Coffee Mug (Chipped, "World’s Best Inflator" Print)** – Holds tangled string.  
- **Dusty "Safety First!" Sign** – Underlined in red marker: *"or else."*  

---  

### **2. The Archive**  
**a. Anchor Furniture & Installations:**  
- **Wall of Specimen Drawers** – 30 small glass-fronted compartments, each labeled (e.g., "Pencil-Type (Actor Grade)", "Mylar-7 (Reactive)").  
- **Locked Display Case (Center)** – Contains a single floating silver balloon, no string.  

**b. Key Interactive & Task-Relevant Objects:**  
- **Logbook** – Open to last entry: *"Test 45: Subject 'Omega' still exhibits anti-grav. Hypothesis: Tethering may stabilize."*  
- **Drawer #14 (Stuck)** – Requires two people to pry open (one holds adjacent drawer shut to avoid domino effect). Inside: **"Neon-Cap" balloons (glow under UV)**.  

**c. Functional Ambient Objects:**  
- **Magnifying Lamp** – Swivel arm stiff from dried adhesive.  
- **Glove Dispenser** – Empty, crumpled latex glove dangling.  

**d. Background & Decorative Objects:**  
- **Fake Plant (Deflated Balloon "Leaves")** – Some popped, revealing wire stems.  
- **"Employee of the Month" Photo (2003)** – Faded, eyes scratched out.  

---  

### **3. Testing Chamber**  
**a. Anchor Furniture & Installations:**  
- **Plexiglass Cube (2m x 2m x 2m)** – Scratched interior, faint rainbow smudges.  
- **Control Panel** – Buttons labeled "VENT," "RECORD," "EMERGENCY SEAL."  

**b. Key Interactive & Task-Relevant Objects:**  
- **"Subject Z-9" Balloon** – Inside cube, drifting erratically. Occasionally *taps* the glass.  
- **Leak Detector** – Flashing yellow: "GAS DETECTED: TRACE ELEMENTS."  

**c. Functional Ambient Objects:**  
- **Observer’s Chair** – Wheels squeak when moved.  
- **Microphone (Suspended)** – Picks up faint whispering when Z-9 moves.  

**d. Background & Decorative Objects:**  
- **Sticky Note on Glass** – *"DO NOT FEED AFTER MIDNIGHT."*  
- **Broken Stopwatch** – Stuck at 00:66.  

---  

## **Scene Affordances and Embedded Potential**  

### **Collaborative Transportation Affordances:**  
- **Helium Tank Replacement** – Full tanks weigh **80kg each**; must be moved in pairs (one steadies, other guides hose connection).  
- **"Billy" Balloon Relocation** – Cage is **120kg**; hoist requires one to operate winch, another to guide.  

### **Reasoning and Tool-Use Affordances:**  
1. **Attribute-Based Reasoning:**  
   - Among five **"Chroma-Knot" adjustment tools** on the worktable, only the **blue-handled one** has the correct torque setting (indicated by a worn "✓" etched near the grip).  
   - Distractor: A **decoy blue-handled screwdriver** in a nearby mug, slightly different shade.  

2. **Compound (Tool-Use) Reasoning:**  
   - **Problem:** The Archive’s locked case requires a **magnetic key** (lost in Storage & Prep, buried under deflated balloons).  
   - **Solution:** Key is inside a **false-bottomed "Confetti Grade" balloon box**—requires comparing box weights to find the anomaly.  

### **Dynamic Environmental Factors:**  
- The **Testing Chamber’s "VENT" button** is jammed—must use a **long-reach tool** (from Main Workshop) to pry it.  
- **"Subject Z-9"** reacts to certain sound frequencies—agents must experiment with the intercom to stabilize it.  

---  

**Final Note:** Every object in this space is a potential puzzle piece. The **mundane clutter** (like the deflated balloon leaves) obscures critical items, while the **peculiar anomalies** (whispering balloons, rogue floating objects) ensure agents must stay observant. The scene is *alive* with collaborative potential—whether it’s wrestling a rogue helium hose or decoding the logbook’s cryptic warnings.
